conclusion: The problem requires finding the magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the metal rod and the resistance value of the rheostat R2.

The metal rod MN is stationary, the magnetic induction intensity B is vertically upward with a magnitude of 0.6 T, the electromotive force (EMF) of the power source is 10 V, the internal resistance of the power source is 1 Ω, the distance between the parallel rails is 15 cm, the mass of the metal rod MN is 17 g, and the resistance R1 is 4 Ω.
The angle between the magnetic field and the metal rod is 30 degrees.
Since the metal rod MN remains stationary, the force F acting on it is equal to its weight, given by F = mg.
The weight of the metal rod is calculated as mg = 0.017 × 10 = 0.17 N.
The Lorentz force law is used to express the force as F = (B × I × L) / R1.
Substituting the known values into the Lorentz force equation: 0.17 = (0.6 × I × 15) / 4.
The current I is calculated as I = 0.17 / 0.9 ≈ 0.18 A.
The resistance R2 of the rheostat is calculated using the formula R2 = (E / I) - r.
Substituting the known values into the formula for R2: R2 = (10 / 0.18) - 1.
The resistance R2 is calculated as R2 ≈ 83.33 Ω.
The magnitude of the Ampere force acting on the metal rod is approximately 0.18 N, and the resistance value of the rheostat R2 is approximately 83.33 Ω.
